thread.title: Iowa St. tough stretch ends with 45-27 loss at No. 2 Baylor
thread.title_full: Iowa St. tough stretch ends with 45-27 loss at No. 2 Baylor

title: Iowa St. tough stretch ends with 45-27 loss at No. 2 Baylor
text:
Tough trifecta ends for Iowa State with 45-27 loss at No. 2 Baylor By STEPHEN HAWKINS AP Sports Writer   6:18   6:18   
People: 
Texas (1310) 

WACO, Texas — Iowa State has hope for the future with plenty of talented youngsters, including freshman running backs and a sophomore quarterback getting more and more snaps. 
For now, it has been a difficult task for the Cyclones facing the top three FBS offenses — and Big 12 Conference foes — in consecutive weeks. 
That tough trifecta wrapped up Saturday with a 45-27 loss to second-ranked Baylor, which was held to a season-low 485 total yards and went more than 35 minutes without a score. 
"We had an opportunity to get an onside kick and pull this game within seven and put ourselves in a position to compete to win the game," Cyclones coach Paul Rhoads said. "You do that on the road in conditions like this against the second-ranked team in the country, you're pleased with the energy and effort they gave." 
That was after Iowa State (2-5, 1-3 Big 12) fell behind 35-0 by the middle of the second quarter with three early turnovers on a rainy day along the Brazos River. 
The Cyclones finally scored when freshman Joshua Thomas had a 3-yard touchdown run with just under 5 minutes left in the first half. 
Joel Lanning, the quarterback sharing more time with senior Sam Richardson, had a pair of touchdown passes after halftime. He threw 2 yards to Quenton Bundrage and then 4 yards to Jauan Wesley with 7:47 left to get the Cyclones within 35-20. 
"When you're down 35-nothing or whatever it was, you don't really think about it," Lanning said. "You've just got to come out and start chipping away at the game. Forget about the score and keep playing." 
While Corey Coleman had two more touchdown catches, Shock Linwood ran for 171 yards and the Bears stretched their FBS-best home winning streak to 20 games, they were held under 60 points for the first time in six games. 
"It's hard to stay at a level that we've been at, energy-wise, emotionally and then production-wise," coach Art Briles said. "It's been insane." 
The only other NCAA team with five consecutive 60-point games was Oklahoma in 2008. The Bears (7-0, 4-0) had 485 total yards, leaving them well below their national-leading averages of 64 points and 720 total yards a game. 
Iowa State, which has lost its last 14 games against ranked teams, gave up 156 points and 1,882 yards in its last three weeks. But the Cyclones led fourth-ranked TCU 21-14 in the first quarter at home a week earlier before the Horned Frogs scored the game's last 31 points. They opened the stretch losing 66-31 at Texas Tech. 
Baylor finished the game without quarterback Seth Russell, who sustained a strained neck on a 4-yard run without about 5 1/2 minutes left. The extent of the injury wasn't known, though there is extra time before the next game. 
"He's a tough guy. It's hard to see tough guys hurt," coach Art Briles said. 
Coleman had a 36-yard score on Baylor's opening drive, then had a downfield block that helped Russell break free on a 37-yard TD run for a quick 14-0 lead. Coleman caught a 12-yarder from Jarrett Stidham in the closing minutes, his FBS-best 18th TD catch this season and the 31st of his career to break Kendall Wright's school record. 
Russell was 16 of 37 for 197 yards and two touchdowns, pushing his FBS-leading total to 29 scores. 
"We're going to take the blame, but the weather was bad, and we couldn't do lot of stuff we usually do," Coleman said. "It was kind of tough catching the ball. It's kind of hard to play when the ball's waterlogged and (for Russell) to try to throw the ball like a shotput. ... It was an ugly win, but we got it."
